utterances: You know, right now, 4th of July stuff.

We're talking about buying and selling with Ellen Ruppel Shell.
She's the author of ""Cheap: The High Cost of Discount Culture.
You're listening to TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
And let's get a caller from overseas.
Mohammed(ph) is on the line.
Mohammed calling from Saudi Arabia.
Yes.
Hello.
This is Mohammed from Saudi Arabia.
Goodnight, Neal and Ellen.
Go ahead.
In fact, in Saudi Arabia, people are more concerned with the quality, not as sensitive to the price as they are in other parts of the world.

But the real problem is that, how can we ensure that the products that we are buying are the real quality, given that there are so many products that you really, really, you know, copy the good quality products and they have fake, you know, country of origin.
And for this reason, the importance of consumer protection and the consumer rating, like when I go and book a hotel on the Internet, I have other consumers rating it.
Right.
So, how can - you know, the issue is that how can we get the community and the consumers themselves to rate the products so other consumers can get an indication of the level of the quality?
And I will ask the question on your behalf, but I did want to ask you a question: Are, these days, most prices set by price tag as they are here in this country?
Or is this still a culture where prices are bargained?
Well, prices are bargained.
It's a free pricing.
Any - all vendors can set their prices, you know, outlets as they wish.
So it's a pure competition market.
And you write about this a lot in your book, Ellen Ruppel Shell.
Yes.
I talk about the ancient bazaar where there was a give and take between buyer and seller.
And if some - if a merchant in the ancient bazaar ripped off his neighbor, he didn't stay in business very long.

So there was a kind of automatic quality control when you knew where the product was made, when you knew that guy who was selling it, and you, you know, knew who his family was, that's a very long time ago, maybe still the case to some degree in Saudi Arabia and other parts of the world.
If you're talking about trying to get millions out of a turnip, you know, it just isn't going to happen, no matter how much you squeeze.
Frankly, if they won their case, probably more likely just to turn around and get the company to agree not to do it again in the future.
How do we know about quality?

Well, a wise man said a long time ago that knowledge in the marketplace is probably the scarcest commodity, you know, really trying to figure out how something is made, where it's made, if you're being fooled.
These are very difficult things to know.
And it's particularly difficult today when we have multinationals making products, who knows where.
We don't really know what goes into them a lot of the time.
So it is - it does certainly behoove consumers to know as much as they possibly can about products.
That's where the Internet comes in handy.
But as one behavioral psychologist told me, people prefer - oftentimes prefer not to research, especially discount buys, because they, again, love to get that hit of a discount.
They don't want to know too much.
Don't ask too much.
You don't want to know too much.
Right, don't ask too much.
Exactly.
Vicky(ph) is on the line.
Vicky calling from La Crosse in Wisconsin.
Hi.
I, you know, I was just saying I think I have a perfect example about what your guest speaker is talking about.

And my example is that, you know, even having a rummage sale, and you have an item that is a beautiful item and you're just willing to give it for as little a price as you want to get rid of it and to give it to somebody who could really use it.
And, like, say, you'd have a dollar on it.
And everything that's going is like 25 cents or 50 cents and you can't figure out why this beautiful item is not going at a dollar.
Interesting enough, you put a $5 mark, you know, signage on it.
And within a minute, it's gone.
Right.
So...
They're saying...
A dollar is junk and $5 is...
...we just take it half.
Yeah.

But it would not sell for a dollar prior.

U.S.
policy in Iraq - it's the focus of an independent panel called the Iraq Study Group.
It's co-chaired by former Secretary of State James Baker - a Republican with very close ties to the Bush family - and former Congressman Lee Hamilton, a Democrat.
The group's suggestions were not supposed to come out until sometime next year, but they are coming out now - or at least the group's current thinking is beginning to leak out.
Doyle McManus is the Washington bureau chief of the Los Angeles Times.
His story on what the Iraq Study Group is thinking is the lead in the paper today.
Doyle McManus, welcome back to DAY TO DAY.
And remind us, where did the Iraq Study Group come from?
Well, that's an interesting story, Alex.
The Iraq Study Group was launched early this year by members of Congress who were afraid that the Bush administration wasn't looking hard enough for alternative policies in Iraq.

And initially, the Bush administration wasn't very enthusiastic about it, but eventually - as it became clear it was going to happen anyway - the president said, yes, he was glad to have this group together.
In fact, Secretary of State Baker - former Secretary Baker went into ask him for his endorsement and got it.
And so, whether it really wanted it or not, the administration got this independent review panel.
But now that things in Iraq have gotten a little bit worse, the administration seems to be warming up to the idea, at least a little bit.
I'll just note a couple of people on here.
The panel's members include the former Supreme Court Justice Sandra Day O'Connor, former director of the CIA Robert Gates.
I mean, this is a high level group.
And what are you learning about what the group is prepared to recommend?
Well, the group asked its experts for a set of options papers to give them the full range of possibilities on Iraq.
At one end was a paper that called for basically a continuation of the current policy.
They sort of threw that one away.
At the other end was one that called for an immediate withdrawal from Iraq.
They threw that away.
And that gave them, in effect, two alternatives in the middle - two options for either tweaking or seriously changing American policy.
